IN the case of Poland there are no physical difficulties in the way of carrying intoeffect the Principle of Nationalities; but we cannot say the same thing of Bohemia.Along a considerable portion of the northern and western borders of the ancientkingdom, Nature and history conspire to establish a frontier which unfortunately doesnot strictly correspond with the ethnological distribution of population. It seems, and perhaps is, absurd to redraw the Bohemian frontier so as to leave in German hands thewhole mountain chain which guards the country from German invasion. Yet if this be not done there will be in the new Ozecho-Slovak state a German element amountingto not less than one-quarter of the whole population, compactly situated, bitterly hostile to their Slav neighbours, and in sympathy with the Saxons, Bavarians, and German-Austrians dwelling beyond their border, and with the German capitalists andGermanised nobles within them.CZECHOSLOVAKSA. J. B.October 18, 1918.
